page.title: 04HILLESDEN CHURCH
page.content: Hillesden Church has been called "The Cathedral in the field". Begun in the 13th century it has had a very chequered history. It was rebuilt by monks in the 14th century. The doors to this day bear the marks of shot fired during the Civil War. At this time too 30 or 40 Royalist prisoners were put to death in the churchyard. Early in the 18th century the church was further damaged by fire. At the beginning of the 19th century this fine building was visited by a young boy from the neighbouring village of Gawcott. It is reputed that Hillesden Church inspired the young Gilbert Scott (later Sir Giles Gilbert Scott) to devote his life to ecclesiastical architecture. Restoration work was carried out in the 1950s.
